reviews.text: It remains genuinely unnerving to this day -- ridiculous in places, faintly despicable in others, but gorgeous to look at and possessed with a sense of absolute, ruthless gravity.
reviews.author: Tom Huddleston

reviews.text: The macabre, obscene demonstrations of manifest evil still retain their power to startle and nauseate, particularly Linda Blair's "head-turning" antics as the possessed child.
reviews.author: Alan Jones

reviews.text: The mindless and hysterical banality of the evil presented in The Exorcist is the most terrifying thing about the film. The Americans should cer­tainly know more about evil than that; if they pre­tend otherwise, they are lying.
reviews.author: James Baldwin

reviews.text: The Exorcist more conspicuously pushed into the mainstream a hitherto disreputable genre.
reviews.author: Dennis Harvey

reviews.text: Seminal and important for good reasons.
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: Perhaps the most influential American horror movie ever made, The Exorcist was a Rorschach test when it came out. Fifty years later, it still sticks with us.
reviews.author: Adam Nayman

reviews.text: The scariest movie ever made...
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: This film's ponderings about the nature of good and evil still merit consideration today. It also features some wonderful performances from Ellen Burstyn, Jason Miller, Max von Sydow and, especially, a then pre-adolescent Linda Blair.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: The movie moves at a pace that is unheard of today; a good hour and a quarter pass before the word "exorcism" is even mentioned. Yet it weaves a frightening spell right from the get-go.
reviews.author: Margaret A. McGurk

reviews.text: The Exorcist remains an exceptionally well-made, thoughtful film, enacted by a first-rate cast and displaying an almost masterful interplay between the humdrum and the horrific.
reviews.author: Robert W. Butler

reviews.text: Friedkin performed a similar alchemy to that of Francis Ford Coppola [with The Godfather]: He took a good, pulpy novel and turned it into a great, enduring movie.
reviews.author: Terry Lawson

reviews.text: Some parts are bound to be greeted by unintentional laughter today, the result of countless parodies over the years. Still, The Exorcist has lost none of its ability to invade your nightmares.
reviews.author: Rene Rodriguez

reviews.text: The Exorcist accomplishes what so few horrormeisters save Stephen King have managed: It sets sin and salvation not in the realm of graveyards and goblins, but in day-to-day life.
reviews.author: John Petkovic

reviews.text: By the end, after the priests had finished their battle for Regan MacNeil's body and soul, I expected to see my frigid breath hanging in the air.
reviews.author: Lawrence Toppman

reviews.text: The Exorcist has dated little, and its essential premise makes it still one of the most modern of horror films. The monster isn't lurking out there. It resides in us, even in the most banal vessel imaginable, a sweet schoolgirl.
reviews.author: Susan Wloszczyna

reviews.text: The tension is created by brilliant direction, tight editing, hydraulics, Linda Blair's makeup and the voice of the Prince of Darkness that chills the spine and showers the body with goosebumps. The acting in this dark movie is flawless, too.
reviews.author: Chris Cobb

reviews.text: It is carefully constructed, filled with nuance, designed to build fear one minute at a time. There can be no escape, no break, just the horror unfolding before your eyes.
reviews.author: Bill Muller

reviews.text: A horror film for grown-ups, paced out carefully, graced by much emotional subtlety and a spirit of intelligent questioning that never lets the viewer of any or no religious persuasion slip into complacency.
reviews.author: John Bentley Mays

reviews.text: Spewing from Blair's 12-year-old mouth via McCambridge's distressed larynx, the script's sexual obscenities are shocking enough to accomplish the virtually impossible and restore the potency of the four-letter word.
reviews.author: Sandra Hall

reviews.text: The Exorcist is a masterful movie three decades later because it was made by filmmakers who had something to say and who knew when to use restraint and when to entertain and when to burrow under your skin.
reviews.author: Christopher Borrelli

reviews.text: Where previously it was an appalling subversion of good taste, subtlety, exposure to Ouija boards and the Catholic stigma of divorce, it now seems clumsy and adolescent.
reviews.author: Wesley Morris

reviews.text: It's still jolting. It's great shock theater.
reviews.author: Jay Carr

reviews.text: The dismissal of The Exorcist as sheer exploitation sells the themes of faith and family short. Besides, manipulative or not, it still stands as one of the most truly horrifying films ever made.
reviews.author: Joshua Klein

reviews.text: What has given The Exorcist legs for all these years is its ability to earn its scares honestly, accruing tension over the course of two hours, releasing it in little spasms of relief and then cranking up the suspense until it is very nearly unbearable.
reviews.author: Marshall Fine

reviews.text: It's still the same old schlock -- a deeply cynical, morally corrupted, often utterly senseless work that has somehow been raised to the status of greatness.
reviews.author: Christopher Kelly

reviews.text: What does impress is the film's early command of suspense. It seems slow to get going, but the malevolence simmering beneath the calm exterior is truly nasty.
reviews.author: Peter Calder

reviews.text: Friedkin's direction pays equal attention to artistry and the gross-out. His camera is never bored, be it an establishing shot or a montage of skull X-rays.
reviews.author: Mark Lepage

reviews.text: Where the film heads south is the elimination of most of the compelling parts of the book... If a film ever needed to add another hour to its length, it's The Exorcist.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: Director William Friedkin builds up the overlapping stories so slowly and deliberately that one might mistake this for a dramatic character study rather than a goose-pimpled thriller. But the goose pimples form anyway.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: The result is a story of surprising intelligence and spiritual power, undiminished over 27 years.
reviews.author: Jack Garner

reviews.text: Director William Friedkin's crude technique, which is basically borrowed from carnival sideshows, looks cornier than ever.
reviews.author: Henry Sheehan

reviews.text: Watching The Exorcist 27 years after its release, it's easy to see how much the movie's story is a product of its times. But the movie worked then, and it still does.
reviews.author: Glenn Whipp

reviews.text: The film so steadily ratchets up the horror that seeing it on commercial television is just plain silly. This is a film that needs to be seen larger-than-life, in a darkened room, with a hundred or so of your most terrified friends.
reviews.author: Chris Kaltenbach

reviews.text: This is Hollywood having it both ways: the spiritual melded with smut.
reviews.author: Eleanor O'Sullivan

reviews.text: This extraordinarily moving and terrifying film has lost none of its power -- it makes the ersatz splatterfests that pass for horror movies these days look like ghoulish cartoons.
reviews.author: Peg Aloi

reviews.text: William Friedkin's disturbing drama set the standard for Satanic themes in movies for years and some of the exorcism images quickly became pop-culture shorthand. See it, if you haven't, but don't eat pea soup beforehand.
reviews.author: Wallace Baine

reviews.text: Although it's clear The Exorcist is no masterpiece, it still retains a powerful charge which most contemporary horror movies have lost in a flurry of post-modern irony and nudgewink jokiness.
reviews.author: Hugh Linehan

reviews.text: A 132-minute jump scare – with horribly malign slow sections – taking place in upper-middle class America rather than some exotic central European locale.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: It is a genuinely shocking movie, which in its ferocious strength and bloodcurdling events denies any possibility that what we are witnessing is anything but a titanic struggle between God and the Devil.
reviews.author: Charles Champlin

reviews.text: The Exorcist is a stunning movie. It is not a pretty movie, and it will repel some, but it hits with explosive force, reveals Jason Miller to be as fine an actor as he is a writer, and is a moving, powerful drama.
reviews.author: Joe Pollack

reviews.text: The Exorcist is far and away the best and most provocative of this season's new releases, tremendously affecting, as visceral as a nightmare. Its flaws are really only flaws of omission.
reviews.author: Janet Maslin

reviews.text: Whatever you may think of the story, you should recognize Friedkin's masterful staging of it. The Exorcist is a spellbinder because Friedkin creates the experience of evil and sustains it for two hours. That's an incredible feat.
reviews.author: Joseph Gelmis

reviews.text: Frankly, The Exorcist is nothing but a superior shocker. A very well-made horror movie, with pretensions to something better (or certainly deeper) that never does more than stick its nose out and then hastily withdraw.
reviews.author: Alexander Walker

reviews.text: If The Exorcist isn't the thinking-man's horror movie we were expecting -- congratulate Friedkin for keeping us thinking when the chill is on.
reviews.author: Judith Crist

reviews.text: Somewhere underneath all this hype, sound and fury there is... An odd mixture of competence, craft and absolute shoddiness. It is far from greatest horror film or supernatural film but it may well be the most expensive and soullessly engineered.
reviews.author: Jeff Simon

reviews.text: The movie is a startling mix of religion, ESP, frenzy, fervent hope, occultism and a heavy-handed dose of diabolism. But don't mistake it... The Exorcist is slam-bang sensationalism. It is an exhaustive, as well as an exhausting shocker.
reviews.author: Kevin Kelly

reviews.text: All things considered, The Exorcist, in terms of shocks per hour, qualifies, at least superficially, as an entertaining film although not a horror classic.
reviews.author: Greg Mims

reviews.text: The sign of the Devil is all over the film, which survived strange troubles in the two years of its making to emerge as a creation of infernal inspection -- cunning, shocking, obscene, outrageously bold and immorally spellbinding.
reviews.author: William B. Collins

reviews.text: It is absolutely, almost unspeakably shocking. But the question is, to what end?... Whatever deeper purpose the film may have had as a study of Christian commitment or moral strength is lost in the more sensationalized aspects.
reviews.author: Dorothy Smiljanich

reviews.text: A great many people will feel both frightened and sick. My own reaction was one of first irritation and then anger that a filmmaker of Friedkin's resource should lend his talent, and that of a good cast, to something so essentially meretricious.
reviews.author: Derek Malcolm

reviews.text: Vomiting, urinating and a great flow of four-letter words are worked in to a picture that seems especially designed to support sensation -- and little else, for the narrative line is weak and the character drawing superficial.
reviews.author: Patrick Gibbs

reviews.text: The Exorcist is a scary film, but no more so than The Haunting or any other well-done ghost story.
reviews.author: R.H. Gardner

reviews.text: The result is a remarkable tribute to the realistic potential of the film medium, yet it numbs the viewer's senses with unnecessary repulsion and noise.
reviews.author: G.J. Fleming

reviews.text: If The Exorcist doesn't knock you out of your seat, it's only because you'll be too stunned to move.
reviews.author: Stanley Eichelbaum

reviews.text: The overreaction to The Exorcist is amazing when you consider the movie was designed and executed as shock entertainment; and since the shocks here are so witless and superficial, they should conceivably have no lasting effect.
reviews.author: Jay Newquist

reviews.text: The real hero of this film is the man who pulled it all together: director William Friedkin, who has well-deserved billing under the title. Friedkin, who cut his film teeth in television, has crafted a masterpiece of narrative filmmaking.
reviews.author: Chris Van Ness

reviews.text: True, the special effects are often impressive and the acting is more than passable, but the whole affair struck me as about as morally edifying and aesthetically satisfying as watching the Gaderene swine plunge into the sea in slow motion.
reviews.author: Philip French

reviews.text: Take away the exorcism and I would have been considerably more impressed by The Exorcist.
reviews.author: Arthur Steele

reviews.text: Whether you believe in the occult or not, The Exorcist is an extremely shocking and compelling movie -- and it also happens to be extremely well-made.
reviews.author: Norman Dresser

reviews.text: Shorn of all the trappings and removed from all the frenzy, in fact, [The Exorcist] is a very well-made movie -- not entirely a satisfactory one, to be sure, but without question an impressive one. Most important of all, it's also a genuinely scary movie.
reviews.author: John Bustin

reviews.text: Sensation-sated though we are these days, The Exorcist makes you realize the tremendous potential within the motion-picture medium, affording power to give images of a lurid novel even greater impact.
reviews.author: Dick Banks

reviews.text: Maybe the movie will bring in hordes of patrons. It is difficult to understand, however, why anyone of sound mind would pay good money to subject himself to so ghastly a movie-watching experience.
reviews.author: Susan Stark

reviews.text: I can't possibly believe that one is supposed to take The Exorcist seriously. It's a childish prank which pretentiously deals with the struggle over evil in narrow Gothic terms.
reviews.author: John J. Massaro

reviews.text: If you have to see one film this year, it may as well be The Exorcist, William Peter Blatty's bizarre story about a demon who takes over a girl's soul. It's a gasp of a film.
reviews.author: Wayne Harada

reviews.text: A grim, poorly paced effort that lacks the two ingredients necessary for total credibility in horror films: Genuine enthrallment and Hitchcockian-style black humor.
reviews.author: Joe Baltake

reviews.text: William Peter Blatty's best-selling novel has been filmed by the talented William Friedkin with even more fidelity than many readers may care for. It is a riveting, stunning experience -- for those who can take it.
reviews.author: George Anderson

reviews.text: It's not a picture I can honestly say I "liked." I did find it an exhausting, stunning emotional traumatic film trip that left me drained for days. It's really "something else" as far as a film goes -- and this goes pretty far.
reviews.author: Montezuma

reviews.text: The Exorcist succeeds on one level as an effectively excruciating entertainment, but on another, deeper level it is a thoroughly evil film.
reviews.author: Andrew Sarris

reviews.text: A finely crafted thriller that benefits immensely from William Friedkin’s controlled direction, William Peter Blatty’s thematically fruitful script, and Dick Smith’s startling makeup designs.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: What is objectionable is not the foulness that comes roaring and Beelze-bubbling out of the screen whenever the possessed girl is on it, but the whoppingly tendentious purpose she is there to serve.
reviews.author: Russell Davies

reviews.text: It is unfortunate that basically The Exorcist is a good film, for the shock tactics have been calculated in a most unconscionable way, and this should have been enough to damn it. However, the cast is superb.
reviews.author: Kenneth Robins

reviews.text: The trouble with the occult is that it spreads like a contagion, preying on the feeble-minded... And so with this film. It supports centuries' old notions of devils and possession without adding any new dimensions of understanding.
reviews.author: Lyn Gambles

reviews.text: It is not for the squeamish. Avoid seeing it after a heavy meal. It also happens to be a technically brilliant film, acted with such persuasive realism as to make the bizarre events totally credible and absorbing.
reviews.author: Arthur Thirkell

reviews.text: The movie project that has managed to annihilate the media, literally "out farthering" The Godfather in both publicity-grabbing and being "far out," is an exceptionally well-crafted motion picture product.
reviews.author: Phil Strassberg

reviews.text: The final result is a witches' brew with cauldrons bubbling with too much frantic mayhem and too many hysterical climaxes occurring before the final climax with its legitimate mayhem.
reviews.author: Bernard Drew

reviews.text: If this cinema of revulsion-for-its-own-sake is what you wish from a medium of art and entertainment, the best of Transylvanian luck to you. Next time you can demand a look at medical films of operations.
reviews.author: Colin Bennett

reviews.text: Although the film has every attention lavished on it, it is much less scarifying than something like Rosemary's Baby, where the grisly happenings did have a sickening plausibility. The Exorcist, however, is simply a superior spook-movie.
reviews.author: Michael Billington

reviews.text: As somebody who feels the ritual of horror should touch the nerve of something within us, I feel that The Exorcist cops out. It shows us everything and, thus, reveals nothing.
reviews.author: Tom Hutchinson

reviews.text: The Exorcist has arrived in all its grim, gory and gruesome glory, and, like a dreaded trip to the dentist's office, isn't nearly as bad a trip as the wary were fearing. What it is, in fact, is a superb shocker.
reviews.author: Elston Brooks

reviews.text: It's a cheap kind of horror because it is nothing more than repulsive spectacle, unattended by sympathy or even suspense.
reviews.author: Giles M. Fowler

reviews.text: The Exorcist is a tough film, often ugly, but compelling and skillfully put together for maximum impact.
reviews.author: Noel Taylor

reviews.text: It cannot be denied that The Exorcist proves the power of film to control your emotions. But it is not proof positive. I think it may well be an evil film, for The Exorcist is itself possessed by the resident house devil of Hollywood: rank commercialism.
reviews.author: David Elliott

reviews.text: [A] terrifying journey into a miasma of religion and guilt and pain, complete with flashes of a demonic face that I still cannot handle seeing unprepared.
reviews.author: Megan Sunday

reviews.text: The Exorcist isn’t just frightening at a visceral level, it’s bleak on an existential level.
reviews.author: Gena Radcliffe

reviews.text: After 50 years, The Exorcist is still scaring us.
reviews.author: Alison Gillmor

reviews.text: What makes The Exorcist so fantastic, however, are the performances...
reviews.author: Howard Waldstein

reviews.text: The restraint and intelligence of William Friedkin’s definitive Cathsploitation movie is at odds with the trend towards overt shocks and sadism in contemporary horror.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: It’s not only one of the best horror films ever made, it’s easily one of the silver screens finest features.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: As much as it has been parodied and referenced and imitated millions of times, it is still one of the best horror movies ever made. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: The director's horrifyingly maintained assault of the viewer's senses and faith leaves the audience subject to devilish, claustrophobic torment that makes the resultant spiritual awakening all the more powerful.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: It's actually kind of astonishing to me that the film still retains the power to shock and frighten a first-time viewer.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: Scary then, scary still. Without a doubt one of the most frightening films ever made. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Remains one of the scariest movies to date given the shocking nature of its subject matter of a little girl possessed by devil, and it's really up to the audience to believe if that can happen or not.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: The makeup is still top-notch and spectacularly chilling, paired perfectly with puppetry and repulsive props for several of the most alarming cinematic shots.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: A product of its time, in the best ways.
reviews.author: Simone de Rochefort

reviews.text: Such perfectionism at the service of trash takes on a lurid, almost indecent, character. Still, Friedkin has a crass expertise with which he can keep the average moviegoer from laughing at these absurd goings-on, and he certainly gets great performances.
reviews.author: John Simon

reviews.text: Simply the most terrifying movie ever made, even now.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: The film continually struggles to suggest through atmosphere what it promises but fails to provide in substance.
reviews.author: Richard Combs

reviews.text: The problem for me is that the movie has no sense of purpose, no convictions.
reviews.author: Dick Lochte

reviews.text: One scary movie that still terrifies me to this day...
reviews.author: Geoff Burns

reviews.text: They went above and beyond...we have movies like The Exorcist to thank for so many other movies...
reviews.author: Chris Stuckmann

reviews.text: This is a powerful movie that continues to stand up today and for good reason too - it's a masterpiece.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: [The Exorcist] may not be a great film. It is, however, a brilliantly successful horror movie.
reviews.author: Kathleen Carroll

reviews.text: Friedkin seems to have found his forte.
reviews.author: Stanley Kauffmann

reviews.text: Without a doubt, "The Exorcist" is a touchstone in horror, seemingly incapable of taking a wrong step. Watching with the lights off is strongly encouraged. Turning them back on immediately afterwards will be a necessity.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: The Exorcist runs out of steam long before reaching its decidedly low-key (and somewhat anticlimactic) finale...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: A work of cinema in its own league.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: The film turns out to be a superior horror story, very ably directed by William Friedkin whose last film was The French Connection.
reviews.author: Christopher Hudson

reviews.text: The Exorcist, with its excellent cast, mounting intensity, and ingeniously constructed surprises, is still a commanding achievement.
reviews.author: Desmond Ryan

reviews.text: The movie that launched a new era in horror films, and which, for one generation, remains one of the scariest experiences of their lives.
reviews.author: Jack Mathews

reviews.text: The Exorcist, like most memorable Hollywood movies, gains its power from the way it mixes opposites: new-style realism and sexual radicalism, old-style horror and religion.
reviews.author: Michael Wilmington

reviews.text: When I first saw The Exorcist, I saw only the literal side of the story. But as I watched it again, I began to view the movie as a dark fairy tale about a parent whose child is experiencing a painful trauma.
reviews.author: Jay Boyar

reviews.text: [Friedkin] knew he wasn't making art; he was concocting gross-out pop -- a movie so "scary" it borders on being silly.
reviews.author: Robert Wilonsky

reviews.text: Von Sydow, Blair and Mercedes McCambridge (the originally uncredited actress who dubbed Regan's gross mutterings) are flat-out terrific.
reviews.author: Lou Lumenick

reviews.text: Less a cleverly spun story than a disjointed collection of shockeroos, surrounding a few ghoulishly effective moments with overcooked plot twists and in-your-face vulgarity.
reviews.author: David Sterritt

reviews.text: William Friedkin's adaptation of William Peter Blatty's novel, with a screenplay by the author, is a dead-serious meditation on the struggle between good and evil.
reviews.author: Enrique Fernandez

reviews.text: Aall The Exorcist does is take its audience for a ride, spewing it out the other end, shaken up but none the wiser.
reviews.author: Chris Peachment

reviews.text: The gold standard of possession films, this works on multiple levels across generations.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: The Exorcist is what it purports to be, no less than one of the best horror films, one of the best films, of all time.
reviews.author: J.C. Maçek III

reviews.text: Through technical virtuosity at every artistic level.. The Exorcist becomes more than a shocking movie: a film with a strong, positive force. I loved it.
reviews.author: Gene Siskel

reviews.text: It's good stuff but, basically, The Exorcist is a museum piece, something to be enjoyed for its historical value, its datedness and its almost quaint shock value.
reviews.author: Desson Thomson

reviews.text: Friedkin's Exorcist holds up remarkably well.
reviews.author: John G. Nettles

reviews.text: This notorious battle between good and evil, nominated for eight Oscars when it was originally released in 1973, is both a hysteric scream and an intentional as well as unintentional hoot.
reviews.author: Mark Halverson

reviews.text: Essential viewing for anyone who loves cinema. If you can endure it...
reviews.author: Total Film Staff

reviews.text: succeeds best in developing its characters
reviews.author: John A. Nesbit

reviews.text: There’s no doubt that the film is an effective button-pusher, even genuinely frightening, but for all its delayed gratification, William Peter Blatty’s script offers precious little in the way of character-building.
reviews.author: Sam Adams

reviews.text: The Exorcist is a movie to make your hair stand on end. And turn your stomach. Unfortunately it may affect your stomach more than it does your hair. For many The Exorcist may well be the movie to be nauseous by.
reviews.author: Tony Mastroianni

reviews.text: What The Exorcist really gave rise to was a demon of entertainment, an impulse of titillating blatancy that has bedeviled and outraged audiences ever since. That demon was kicky and gross and fun and purgative.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: There's something new to be discovered in every viewing of The Exorcist.
reviews.author: Eugene Novikov

reviews.text: Max von Sydow brings gravity and fragility to Father Merrin, the discoverer of Pazuzu who becomes the spectral figure in black beneath the street lamp in the celebrated poster.
reviews.author: Malcolm Johnson

reviews.text: This is a movie that believes in evil, and sees no point in dancing around the inevitable acknowledgments.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: But, is it just me, or is Karras's the only story that's really compelling?
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: Taken as a whole, The Exorcist is not the icon of terror it once was, but it's still a solid film with a lot to recommend it, and a must for those with an interest in horror history.
reviews.author: Jennie Kermode

reviews.text: It just never gets un-scary. That's the best part.
reviews.author: Scott Weinberg

reviews.text: Trendsetting shocker about a possessed child.
reviews.author: Charles Cassady

reviews.text: An unforgettable horror film that doesn't just get under my skin - it stays there.
reviews.author: R.L. Shaffer

reviews.text: ...the movie is right up there with the cinema's better chillers.
reviews.author: John J. Puccio

reviews.text: If it failed on all other levels (which it doesn't), The Exorcist would nevertheless be an excellent family horror story.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: From the day of its first release in 1973, "The Exorcist: was the greatest horror film ever made, and it remains so to this day.
reviews.author: Steve Biodrowski

reviews.text: ... a crude religious exploitation piece (although poor Linda Blair - required to urinate, swear and vomit on cue - is exploited more than anything else).
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: The overall film has a well-developed sense of atmosphere that most films of today are missing.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Friedkin and Blatty seem to care nothing for their characters as people, only as victims-props to be abused, hurled about the room, beaten and, in one case, brutally murdered.
reviews.author: Jay Cocks

reviews.text: The Exorcist is not an unintelligently put-together film, which makes one all the more impatient with it.
reviews.author: Vincent Canby

reviews.text: If movies are, among other things, opportunities for escapism, then The Exorcist is one of the most powerful ever made.
reviews.author: Roger Ebert

reviews.text: A story whose archetypal pull and sheer visceral power can't be negated by even the worst audience behaviour.
reviews.author: Gemma Files

reviews.text: There's something elemental about The Exorcist.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: There is nothing dated about The Exorcist, which remains an effective excursion into demonic possession more than a quarter of a century after it was first unveiled to the public.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: The film is an intense rollercoaster ride, a marvel of audience manipulation, with director William Friedkin pushing all the right buttons to make this a genre landmark.
reviews.author: TV Guide Staff

reviews.text: The Exorcist is an expert telling of a supernatural horror story. The well cast film makes credible in powerful laymen's terms the rare phenomenon of diabolic possession.
reviews.author: A.D. Murphy

reviews.text: It stimulates and rewards, time and time again.
reviews.author: Andrew Collins

reviews.text: This is the dark frightening place where modern horror cinema began.
reviews.author: Film4 Staff

reviews.text: This 1973 horror thriller is highly instructive as well as unnerving.
reviews.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum

reviews.text: Totally ludicrous.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: One of the few horror films that hold up well, The Exorcist is still scary due to the visual and sound effects, but it's also well-written by Blatty, well-directed by Friedkin, and well-acted by Ellen Burstyn as the mother and Linda Blair as her daughter
reviews.author: Emanuel Levy

reviews.text: Arguably the most troubling factor is the lack of true redemption in the twist ending, which resolves the demon possession without allowing good to triumph over evil.
reviews.author: Steven D. Greydanus

reviews.text: As it gets into the minds of its characters, it finds powerful suspense and drama. And a startling examination of how we can never really understand the nature of mankind... or God.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: Barbarism and exploitation here parade as something deeper. Abominable.
reviews.author: Jake Euker

reviews.text: The scariest movie I have ever seen. So scary, I refuse to watch it again.
reviews.author: Willie Waffle

reviews.text: If horror movies constitute a distillation of the basic struggle of good vs. evil, The Exorcist delivers it in the most profound way: inviting us to meditate on the universe around us while still scaring the pants off of us at every turn.

reviews.text: A sour odor of spiritual guilt wafts through every fascinating minute of The Exorcist.

reviews.text: Absolutely timeless horror in its purest form. Seeing this recently with a bunch of rambunctious college students, not even they were immune. Exorcism time came around--you could hear a pin drop in the cinema.

reviews.author: Tim Dirks

synopsis: One of the most profitable horror movies ever made, this tale of an exorcism is based loosely on actual events. When young Regan (Linda Blair) starts acting odd -- levitating, speaking in tongues -- her worried mother (Ellen Burstyn) seeks medical help, only to hit a dead end. A local priest (Jason Miller), however, thinks the girl may be seized by the devil. The priest makes a request to perform an exorcism, and the church sends in an expert (Max von Sydow) to help with the difficult job.
